text:
The Holland Tunnel- Full sized section Hudson River Vehicular Tunnel, 29'-6" diameter (Weight of rong per linear foot 16630#) and full sized section of Hudson & Manhattan R.R. Tunnel under Hudson River, 16'-7" Diameter. (Weight of ring per linear foot 5670#) (cast in 1902).

photograph originally taken at Bethlehem Steel Co.'s Plant, Bethelhem Pa. on Han. 19, 1923 at 3:30 p.m. enlarged with air currents in the Vehicular Tunnel and an enlarged truck; also with the interior of the Hudson & Manhattan Tunnel correctly shown.
2-13-1924
title: Tunnels - [Vehicular Tunnels] - Holland Tunnel [Hudson River Vehicular Tunnel.]

text:
The convergence of Vestry (left) and Canal (right) at Varick Streets. The view is westward and shows in the foreground the 5 story, triangular Holland Tunnel Administration Building. On the extreme right appears a portion of the Manhattan exit of the Holland Tunnel.

P. L. Sperr.

Holland Tunnel vehicular traffic.
About 1927.
Irving Galloway.
title: Transportation - Motor vehicles - [Holland Tunnel vehicular traffic.]

text:
(1)
Watts Street, south side, from No. 99, east of Hudson Street, to No. 51, east of Varick, inclusive. Nos. 99 to 75, the group of old houses west of, adjoining and at Varick Street, S.W. corner, are shortly to be demolished for the site of the Holland Plaza Building. A number of these old houses are brick faced frame houses, specifically Nos. 91-89, 83, 81, 79, and 75 at the corner. The last is faced with brick on the 93 Varick Street side.
October 11, 1928.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
The same, seen from Hudson Street, four months later, when the entire block has been cleared off except for a few trees. The large white building is on the east side of Varick Street (q.v.) from Watts Street to Grand.
February 25, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.

Watts Street, south side, from No. 99, east of Hudson Street, to No. 51, east of Varick, inclusive. (1)
Holland Plaza, Hudson Street, east side, from Watts Street towards Broome, and just including the entrance to the Holland Vehicular Tunnel.
March 20, 1932.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
The same, a year later, including a little of the new building at the Nor-Ea corner of Broome Street.
June 3, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.

(3)
The same, showing a closer view of the entrance to the tube. Note the Church of Our Lady of Vilna R.C., No. 570 Broome Street, adjoining the N.W. corner of Varick Street.
July 27, 1935.

P. L. Sperr.

Holland Tunnel Plaza (westbound traffic), Watts Street, north side, from Hudson Street to Varick Street, inclusive.
June 3, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.

State line looking toward N.J. in the West bound tube.

The continuous slot above the curb is where the fresh air comes in; the openings in the ceiling are for exit of fould or vitiated air.
title: Tunnels - [Vehicular Tunnels] - Holland Tunnel [Hudson River Vehicular Tunnel.]
